definitions: relating to telecommunications systems capable of transmitting data at high speeds over multiple channels
covering or using a wide range of frequencies or wavelengths in signal transmission
examples: The broadband connection enables faster internet browsing speeds
Our broadband service offers speeds up to one gigabit
The broadband spectrum allows multiple simultaneous transmissions
This broadband antenna receives signals across many frequencies

definitions: describing plants, especially trees, that have wide flat leaves rather than needles
examples: The broadleaf forest provides dense shade in summer
These broadleaf trees lose their leaves in autumn

definitions: positioned or directed from the side rather than front or back
characterized by harsh, direct criticism or attack on someone or something
examples: The broadside collision damaged both vehicles severely
The ship turned broadside to face the enemy
Her broadside attack on the policy shocked everyone
The newspaper published a broadside critique of the mayor

definitions: having no money; completely lacking in financial resources or funds
examples: After paying rent, he was completely broke
The broke students survived on instant noodles

definitions: damaged or separated into pieces; no longer in one piece or working order
not operating or functioning properly; out of order or inoperative
emotionally damaged, devastated, or deeply hurt by loss or disappointment
interrupted in continuity; having gaps, pauses, or incomplete segments
examples: The broken window needs immediate replacement
She swept up the broken glass carefully
The broken elevator forced everyone to use stairs
My broken phone won't turn on anymore
His broken spirit never recovered from the loss
She felt broken after the devastating betrayal
Her broken English was difficult to understand
The broken line on the graph indicates missing data

definitions: relating to or affecting the bronchi, the main airways leading from the windpipe to the lungs
examples: The bronchial infection required immediate antibiotic treatment
She suffered from chronic bronchial asthma

definitions: having the brownish-gold color characteristic of bronze metal
made from or coated with bronze, an alloy of copper and tin
representing third place in a competition, especially in sports
examples: Her bronze skin glowed in the sunlight
The bronze sunset painted the sky beautifully
The bronze statue stood in the town square
These bronze fittings resist corrosion better
The bronze medal winner celebrated on the podium
Their bronze performance earned them third place

definitions: having a color or appearance resembling bronze; brownish-gold or copper-colored
examples: The bronzy shimmer of her eyeshadow caught the light
The leaves turned a beautiful bronzy hue in autumn

definitions: showing deep thought often with dark or troubled emotions; moodily contemplative
having a dark, threatening, or ominous quality suggesting coming trouble
examples: His brooding expression worried his friends
The brooding teenager spent hours alone in thought
The brooding clouds promised an approaching storm
The brooding atmosphere in the room made everyone nervous

definitions: showing the affection, loyalty, or kindness characteristic of a good brother
examples: His brotherly advice helped me through difficult times
They shared a warm brotherly embrace

definitions: having the color of earth, wood, or coffee; a dark yellowish-red
having skin darkened by exposure to the sun; tanned or bronzed
examples: The brown leather sofa dominated the living room
Her brown eyes sparkled with amusement
His brown arms showed hours of outdoor work
Their faces were brown from the summer sun

definitions: having a color that is slightly or somewhat brown; tending toward brown
examples: The brownish water indicated high sediment content
Her hair had brownish highlights in the sunlight

definitions: causing or likely to cause bruises through physical impact or pressure
extremely harsh, damaging, or difficult, especially emotionally or competitively
examples: The bruising tackle left him sore for days
She endured a bruising workout at the gym
The bruising election campaign exhausted all candidates
It was a bruising battle for market dominance

definitions: having dark brown or black hair and often darker skin tone
examples: The brunet actor was perfect for the role
Her brunet features contrasted with her sister's blonde hair

definitions: having dark brown or black hair, typically describing women or girls
examples: The brunette woman stood out among the blondes
She dyed her hair to become brunette

definitions: having a surface treated with brushing to create texture or finish
having been lightly touched or swept as if by a brush
examples: The brushed aluminum surface resisted fingerprints well
She wore a soft brushed cotton shirt
His brushed hair looked neat and professional
The brushed leaves rustled in the breeze

definitions: covered with or characterized by dense shrubs, bushes, or undergrowth
having a texture or appearance resembling a brush; bristly or bushy
examples: The brushy hillside made hiking difficult
Deer often hide in brushy areas
His brushy beard needed serious grooming
The brushy texture of the fabric felt rough

definitions: markedly short and abrupt in manner or speech, often to the point of rudeness
examples: His brusque response offended the customer
The doctor's brusque manner intimidated nervous patients

definitions: describing champagne or sparkling wine with very little residual sugar; extremely dry
examples: They served brut champagne at the wedding reception
This brut prosecco pairs well with seafood

definitions: savagely violent, cruel, or harsh in a physical way
unpleasantly harsh or severe in manner, conditions, or effects
examples: The brutal attack shocked the entire community
The brutal dictator ruled with an iron fist
The brutal winter killed many plants
She faced brutal criticism for her decision

definitions: involving or relying on physical strength alone without reason or intelligence
lacking refinement, intelligence, or sensitivity; crude and unthinking
examples: They used brute force to open the door
The problem required brute strength, not finesse
His brute ignorance of social norms embarrassed everyone
The brute reality of poverty shocked the volunteers

definitions: resembling or characteristic of a brute; savage, cruel, or coarse in manner
examples: His brutish behavior at dinner appalled the guests
The brutish treatment of prisoners violated human rights

definitions: producing or characterized by bubbles rising through liquid or appearing on surface
full of cheerful high spirits; vivacious and enthusiastic
examples: The bubbling pot of soup smelled delicious
We heard bubbling water from the nearby stream
Her bubbling personality brightened everyone's day
The children were bubbling with excitement

definitions: containing bubbles; effervescent or fizzy, especially describing drinks
full of cheerful high spirits; animated and enthusiastic in personality
examples: The bubbly champagne tickled her nose
This bubbly water is refreshingly carbonated
Her bubbly personality made her popular at parties
The bubbly hostess greeted each guest warmly

definitions: relating to or characterized by bubonic plague, a disease causing swollen lymph nodes
examples: The bubonic plague devastated medieval Europe
Bubonic symptoms include painful swollen lymph nodes

definitions: relating to the pleasant aspects of countryside and country life; charmingly rural
examples: The bucolic landscape inspired many artists
They enjoyed a bucolic existence far from city stress

definitions: beginning to develop or show signs of future potential in a career or skill
examples: The budding artist showed remarkable talent
Their budding romance was obvious to everyone

definitions: relating to or concerning a budget, especially financial planning and allocation
examples: The budgetary constraints limited their options
They faced serious budgetary challenges this year

definitions: having a pale yellowish-brown color like undyed leather
having a physically fit, muscular body from exercise and training
examples: The buff envelope contained important documents
She painted the walls a warm buff color
The buff athlete impressed everyone at the gym
He got really buff after months of training

definitions: equipped with hidden electronic listening devices for secret surveillance
feeling annoyed, bothered, or worried about something
examples: The bugged office revealed corporate espionage
They discovered their phones were bugged
She seemed really bugged about the test results
He looked bugged by the constant interruptions

definitions: infested with or containing many insects or bugs
containing errors or defects that prevent proper operation, especially in software
examples: The buggy campsite made sleeping difficult
This buggy weather brings out all the mosquitoes
The buggy software crashed repeatedly
Their buggy code needed extensive debugging

definitions: constructed or assembled; having been put together or erected
having a particular body build or physique, especially when muscular
examples: The newly built house featured modern amenities
This well built bridge can support heavy traffic
The powerfully built wrestler dominated his opponents
She was slightly built but surprisingly strong

definitions: fat, round, or bulging in shape; resembling a bulb
examples: His bulbous nose dominated his face
The plant had strange bulbous roots

definitions: swelling or protruding outward; sticking out in a rounded form
examples: His bulging muscles strained against his shirt
The bulging suitcase wouldn't close properly

definitions: taking up much space, typically inconveniently so; large and difficult to handle
examples: The bulky furniture was hard to move upstairs
She struggled with her bulky winter coat

definitions: designed to prevent bullets from penetrating; impervious to bullets
impossible to criticize, disprove, or find fault with; completely protected
examples: The bulletproof vest saved the officer's life
They installed bulletproof glass in the bank
Her bulletproof alibi cleared her of suspicion
He thought his plan was bulletproof

definitions: excellent or admirable; first-rate (informal, dated usage)
examples: That's a bully idea for the celebration
They did a bully job organizing the event

definitions: using superior strength or influence to intimidate or coerce someone
examples: His bullying behavior made coworkers uncomfortable
The bullying tactics of the corporation angered consumers

definitions: of poor quality; worthless, useless, or not functioning properly
examples: He got a bum deal on that car
My bum knee keeps me from running

definitions: acting in a confused, ineffectual way; prone to making mistakes
examples: The bumbling detective accidentally solved the case
His bumbling attempts at cooking amused everyone

definitions: having an uneven surface with many bumps; not smooth
characterized by difficulties, setbacks, or irregular progress
examples: The bumpy road made driving uncomfortable
The bumpy texture helped with grip
They had a bumpy start to their relationship
The company faced a bumpy transition period

definitions: able to stay afloat or rise to the surface of a liquid
cheerful and optimistic; able to recover quickly from setbacks
examples: The buoyant material kept the life jacket afloat
Cork is naturally buoyant in water
Her buoyant personality lifted everyone's spirits
The team remained buoyant despite the loss

definitions: carrying or bearing a heavy load or weight
troubled, oppressed, or weighed down by responsibility, guilt, or problems
examples: The burdened mule struggled up the mountain path
Burdened shoppers navigated through the crowds
She felt burdened by family expectations
The burdened taxpayers demanded reform

definitions: causing difficulty or worry; hard to bear or deal with
examples: The burdensome regulations slowed business growth
Caring for elderly parents became burdensome

definitions: relating to or characterized by excessive administrative procedures and red tape
examples: The bureaucratic process delayed the project for months
She hated dealing with bureaucratic obstacles

definitions: beginning to grow or increase rapidly; flourishing or expanding
examples: The burgeoning tech industry attracted many investors
Their burgeoning friendship surprised mutual acquaintances

definitions: placed underground or beneath something; interred or covered
hidden, concealed, or obscured from view or awareness
examples: The buried treasure remained undiscovered for centuries
Buried cables run beneath the street
The buried emotions finally surfaced during therapy
Important details were buried in the report

definitions: relating to theatrical entertainment featuring broad comedy and exaggerated parody
examples: The burlesque performance mocked political figures
Her burlesque interpretation of the role entertained audiences

definitions: large and strong in build; heavily built and muscular
examples: The burly bouncer stood guard at the door
His burly frame filled the doorway completely

definitions: damaged, injured, or marked by fire, heat, or caustic substances
emotionally hurt or damaged by a bad experience, especially in relationships
examples: The burned toast filled the kitchen with smoke
His burned skin required immediate medical attention
She felt burned by his betrayal
He's been burned before in business deals
